subject: Re: [junit] fundamental questions on JUnit
msgSnippet: ... My first move here would be to ensure that the code looks like this: if (some condition is true) { return doSomeWork(); } else { return doSomeOtherWork();
messageBody:
Anil and Rita Philip wrote:

> I shall try to explain more clearly:
>
> if(some condition is true) {
> do some work;
> return result1;
> }
> else {
> do some other work;
> return result2;
> }
>
> Here are two execution paths within a procedure. Both
> result1 and result2 might be identical in value some
> of the time, for a many to one function. Using Junit,
> how can one know that both paths have been exercised
> or tested?
>

My first move here would be to ensure that the code looks like this:


if (some condition is true) {
return doSomeWork();
}
else {
return doSomeOtherWork();
}


(Note that the work is being performed in other methods, rather than in
inlined code.)

Then I'd write tests for both doSomeWork() and doSomeOtherWork() to verify
that they return the expected results in context.

Then I'd probably write a test for the code above to verify that it returns
the expected result when the condition is both true and false.

Mike
